>>69624397
Stabilizer muscles are a meme, there is no secondary class of muscles called “stabilizers”. Strength is a skill, so squats will make you better at staying stable under heavy loads, but that doesn’t mean there are these little muscles called stabilizers that you’re training. Squats will train your core (abs and to an extent obliques and lower back) in addition to your legs though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69624397
>how do you know that your stabilizing muscles are getting stronger?
You know because you are getting stronger in the lift with consistent form.
If your body detects instability, it will hinder force output.
Best example is a total noob doing bench or press or OHP. You know, a shaky unstable mess with 95lbs for a few reps or whatever. Their chest, delts and triceps can probably produce enough force to lift more than that if you measured it in isolation, but the nervous system won't let them because everything involved in stabilizing the weight is underdeveloped.

>>69624383
SS/SL but based:

>A
squat 3x5
bench 3x5
row (any kind, barbell, db, cable, in my experience i've hurt multiple times doing rows with barbells so i stick to dbs and cables) 3x5
bicep exercise
tricep exercise
bicep exercise
tricep exercise

>B
ohp 3x5
row again 3x5
deadlift 1x5
bicep exercise
tricep exercise
bicep exercise
tricep exercise

dropset the bicep and triceps exercises: 1st set has to be heavy, pick a weight that you can at least rep 8 times and go to failure, 2nd set drop 20% of the weight and go to failure again, 3rd set again drop 20% of the weight and go to failure.

once bench start to get really heavy you can start doing it at the beginning of the workout and leave squat as the second lift, same goes for deadlift, once it gets really heavy start the B workout with it, leaving heavy deadlifts as last main lift will end up getting your hurt because you're fatigued therefore you'll execute the movement with poor form. 4 arms exercises per sessions may seem a lot but trust me, the arms end up being underdeveloped muscles in these programs, they do need to get a lot of work done in order to grow (in my experience at least)

Like Archimedes said it's all about counter-balancing weights on a vertical and horizontal axis with a centre mass of gravity and making sure to fix imbalances otherwise other parts of the body will overcompensate (like big quads compensating for weak glutes) or you will have your spine out of axis and have posture ''fixes'' like swayback/anterior/posterior pelvic tilt due to lack of proper weight to counterbalance either frontward or backward, upper (swayback) or lower body (pelvic tilt).

It really can all be boiled down to 3D geometry and physics.

>>69613738
swayback is caused by overdevelopment of front-ward projected weight on the lower body. Picture the S axis of a healthy spine. Your swayback must over-project backwards and at a height (high upper body), to counter for the weight pulling you front-ward/down in your legs.
You must develop your glutes/hamstrings. I suppose your quads are the over-developed part of your body? Supposing you are fit/have muscle. Otherwise it might be your pot belly or beer gut, who knows or your fat meaty thighs.

Regardless try and straighten up the weight front to back, upper to lower.

The Simple way to explain the principle for the solution, the formula is :
>identify which part of your muscle chain is under-developed/over-developed. Where is the weight causing you to lean back located? If it is not extra weight, is it lack of weight to balance out a harmonious development in another area. Say well developed quads, but no glutes/hammies?
Then work on building it up to balance, and adjust your posture accordingly, feel for where the loss of balance happens, where in the body does the weight start to topple you fro or back. I don't want to give specific exercises/routine because it is more of a matter of the individual body, and a variety of different case scenarios might be happening.
Take a good look in the mirror and do a few ''keep your balance'' exercises to test out exactly where the imbalance in terms of mass might be located. Troubleshoot it. I believe in you anon, you will figure it out.

>>69613465
1. Retract your neck like you're disgusted by or cringing at something. Tilt your head up slightly so that the bottom of your jaw is parallel with the ground. That's good cervical posture.

2. Take both of your hands and grab your chest. Keep your shoulders in that position, then let your arms fall down. That's good thoracic posture.

3. Flex your glutes with a fair amount of effort. Your dick should now be pressing up against your pants. Congratulations, your lumbar spine is in neutral alignment.

Most of this is simple isometric endurance. This is lost among people that live sedentary lives, and/or work desk jobs.

Questions That Don't Deserve Their Own Thread

Don't

>Ask non-fitness or relationship questions

Unless you've been working out for a while already, no.

Few can beat Starting Strength, Strong Lifts 5x5, and Greyskull Lift Pull.

Read the nutrition facts and decide for yourself.

Look into volume eating. Also every time you sit down to eat, also pour yourself a big glass of water and take a sip after every bite. Take the time to focus on chewing each bite and really appreciate the food. You want eating to take longer and to have each meal.

Something that helped me a lot, being in a similar situation in the past (healthy weight bf% now) was looking for more healthy recipes to replace the foods I couldn't stop eating. There's literally millions of recipes out there so you are going to find recipes for food that is healthier and tastes better than what you're currently eating so long as you look hard enough. I love snacking on prawns, for example. Excellent diet food and I prefer them over most junk food. You gotta find something like that for you. Just be careful about watching food videos while hungry, they can induce unwanted eating. On the same note, you can skip eating for a few hours if you get super focused on something. For me, that would be something like drawing, gaming, or rock climbing.

Beginner here, been squatting for two months, should I learn how to low bar squat properly?
High bar placement (somewhere behind upper traps, I push into them to secure the bar, narrow grip) feels natural and secure, and I have the mobility/leverages to do them with decent form most of the time. Long torso, short leg kind of build.
The only issue is that when going heavy, the 1-2 last reps in a set I fold over out of the bottom to engage hip drive. Dunno if relevant but I am much stronger in all pulling variations (I RDL more weight for sets of 10 with full pause and hamstring stretch at bottom than I can squat for sets of 5).
So I figure that I might as well learn low bar so I can fold over from the start, and enjoy more weight on the bar for ego reasons in stead of parking the weight at "technical" failure which I am doing right now. Best recent top set I did was 225lbs for 5, last two reps was ugly as sin.

posts.com:
>>69621695
There are three main factors.

>How much sunlight you get
This is straightforward. Most people do not get enough sunlight, period. Ideally you get some exposure to the whole body, but in this case, your face is paramount.

>Your diet and exercise
You are what you eat. When I was about 21 I went 60 days only eating meat with supplements, and after about 3 weeks all of my zits and even my blackheads literally disappeared. If your acne is this bad, you must pay careful attention to any crappy food you eat. Exercise doesn't directly affect your skin, but the act of sweating profusely and then washing yourself off after is the only true way to clean your pores out properly. Warm water shower for the cleanse, then the last minute or so turn it cold to close the pores. By the way, this is the main reason girls often have nasty face acne, they never sweat and cake their pores in makeup.

>How much crap your face is exposed to.
I.e. dirt and bacteria. If you work a dirty job, or touch your face a lot, its gonna make your skin worse, plain and simple. If you are a faggot and never wash your bed linens, you're gonna have more acne more than likely. Keep towels and linens clean weekly (or more if you notice they get greasy fast), and don't touch your face all the goddamn time.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69624729
As for the immediate treatment, you can go into almost any grocery store and buy a bottle of iodine (this is essentially the stuff hospitals lather on your before surgery to disinfect the area): if I notice the redness that indicates a zit is forming, or if an unsightly whitehead has already formed, I'll use the iodine dropper on it in the evening (it stains your face temporarily so dont do this before work in the morning or before a night on the town). This kills the infection right and proper.

Also, force popping shit is generally a no-no, but in your pic you have those "low-pressure" zits that likely pop without much pressure. I usually pop those kinds and then apply iodine, but thats personal preference, it feels like I'm really cleaning it out that way. I will never force a pimple if its got a lot of pressure or is still mostly red, you're just asking for skin damage at that point.

Not him but I did therapy for 2 years (no meds) and concluded that, although most therapists are good people who want the best for their patients, the industry requires people to not get better. The moment you're healed is the moment you stop paying them.

My therapist admired that I was proactive about things, reading books in addition to our sessions, always asking for advice on the next step or technique. But ultimately they were only trained to help me talk through what I was going through, never to make things better.

I forgot who said it but some Ivy league psych professor is outspokenly against therapy, and says the same stuff, notably: "knowing more about the negatives in your life doesn't help you change them. You can study your negatives intimately, and in the end you're still just left with the knowledge of whats bad, and how to fix it. So save the time and money and just fix it".

So now that's what I do.

>>69622613
My responses to threads like this always get buried, but:

For shirts and pants, lots of brands now carry athletic fit, but you should still experiment. For example, Banana Republic's athletic fit dress shirts would be awesome, but the sleeves are too tight. That said, their athletic fit pants are decent-ish. I adore the fit of Barbell Apparel shirts, but they're admittedly wildly overpriced.

For dress shirts/flannels/whatever, I buy normal sized shit and get it tailored down. Brooks Brothers' semi-slim fit shirt (Regency, I think? It's been a while) work well because the sleeves are still fairly large, but you can tailor in the waist a bit. Ditto for most flannels. I try to avoid adding darts to the back of most shirts, as I think it can fuck up the silhouette more than most tailors think. I'd much rather just crank in from the sides.

For suits, I get everything tailored nowadays. Be super paranoid about their measurements of your shoulders and thighs, that's often where tailors fuck up the most. Nothing should ever fit like the OP photo, that shit is terrible. In my experience, doing cheap M2M (like Indochino) is way better than trying to cram yourself into some one-size-fits-all shit from Suitsupply or Brooks Brothers.

yogurt is unironically my favorite protein choice of all time so far, my second is protein powder. I only happen to eat chicken breast the most cuz of convenience (hard to take dairy to lunch)

I come from a culinary family so being the fat fuck I was I am burdened to know when a meal sucks ass. With yogurt 0%-5% mind you, depending on if you need calories or not, can serve as an ingredient, main dish, side, dessert or appetizer, and can also be used as savory or sweet.

If you don't believe me for savory, consider adding some garlic/onion and some other spices to LIGHT bit of yogurt, adding a single or few pieces of a creamy cheese as well, and then eating it on tortilla or chips or anything. That's just an example of course I know many more, including making a higher volume peanut butter for people who like that.


With that being said, when I was first eating NONFAT PLAIN GREEK YOGURT specifically, I literally had to plug my nose and was brought to tears consuming it, that's how bad it was to me. I now eat it plain out of the container, and it actually became a binge food for me for a minute.

On the ingredient side, consider that I also use protein powder to make pancakes, treats, etc. And the only 2 other ingredients next to Pro-Powder are Egg Whites, and Yogurt, and possibly applesauce (but it's good to use butter instead of Applesauce, fat is good for you, learned that the hard way)

After culturing your yogurt you can eat it as is or make a higher concentration greek style yogurt by draining with cheesecloth/muslin for a few hours. What is drained out is a liquid whey, called acid whey, which is very sour.

When making cheese after you culture and coagulate with rennet, the liquid cooked off the cheese curds is a sweet tasting "sweet whey" which you can freeze or drink as is for a whey protein drink or process further to make whey powder.

>>69616912
I'm not going to say you're wrong, just that there's no scientific reason to be worried. What we understand about radiation is that the kind of radiation that harms human cells (sunlight, for example) is distinct in its ability to disrupt molecular bonds. Electromagnetic radiation is non-ionising, it can push molecules around, but it can't disrupt their bonds. Microwave radiation is similarly harmless in that it is also non-ionising.

>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3226506/

>Although there remains some uncertainty, the trend in the accumulating evidence is increasingly against the hypothesis that mobile phone use can cause brain tumors in adults.
>The Interphone Study, as well as some previous case–control studies (Inskip et al. 2001; Muscat et al. 2000) and the only large cohort study (Schüz et al. 2006), identified a reduced risk of brain tumors among mobile phone users compared with nonusers.
>Key findings were a significantly diminished risk of both glioma and meningioma in regular users compared with people who were not users or were occasional users (“nonusers”); no trend in risk of either tumor type with cumulative hours of use but an apparent raised risk of glioma, and to a lesser extent meningioma, in those in the top decile of cumulative hours of use; and no relation of risk of either tumor type to cumulative number of calls, years of use, or years since first use.
>Finally, participants who had been using mobile phones the longest (≥ 10 years) and had accumulated highest lifetime call hours (≥ 1,640 hr) might be expected a priori to have been at the highest risk if RF exposure were tumorigenic. This was not the case, however, for either glioma (OR = 1.34; 95% CI: 0.90, 2.01) or meningioma (OR = 0.95; 95% CI: 0.56, 1.63) (Interphone Study Group 2010).

>>69624403
I wouldn't worry about a path, because there are so many different fields/sectors/roles/specialties you can get into that it's not possible to pick any one path and go from A to B. Focus on getting your first job, and doing your absolute best to not suck at it. Get it on your resume, and once you feel like you're not learning or that you're unhappy and not likely to become happy in the same position, apply elsewhere or even for a transfer within the same company. When you're inexperienced, it's important to try to find a mentor or a team that is willing to take the time to show you the ropes and teach you concepts. Not just how to do something but why you do it.

I also wouldn't worry about a specific stack, because half of them are memes and the other half are just different dialects of the same shit. Java vs C#, Javascript vs Python... yes they're different, but if you focus on learning how to approach a problem and break it down and solve one part at a time, you'll be fine in any language.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides
https://trackstarusa.com/
>I want to run a fast 5k, 10k, half-marathon, or marathon
https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)
>Stretching guide
https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIXVDdH3o6g
>Performance calculator

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69605967
The long, sustained periods of moderately elevated heart rate stimulates capillary development and improves hematocrit level.
That way, when you do run at redline, your body has become more efficient at quickly transporting oxygen to your muscles.

You're not going to get that development if you just run 20 minutes and exhaust yourself.

By the way, this isn't some bit of bro-science that /run/ developed on its own. This is coaching practice at all levels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69606255
Weight training is easier, gains come faster, and the floor for what is considered "good" is lower.

Also, getting good at running simply requires more of a commitment. You can be a fat blob who eats like shit and still manages 1/2/3/4. I know, because that was me in high school. Getting fast, meanwhile, requires a more comprehensive approach to fitness.

Think about it this way: if 1/2/3/4 is considered the borderline between weak and strong, then 20/42 is the 5k/10k running equivalent.
However, if the question is, how fast can I get running in the same amount of time it takes to get to 1/2/3/4 then the 5k/10k equivalent would probably be sub-25 minutes and sub-1 hour.

You bring up a good point, namely, what are you training for? If you're looking to actually achieve some kind of specific result over a set distance, then you need to train and do the boring work. If you just want some cardio, do whatever you want to keep cardio fun.

It's no different than weightlifting. If you're training for some specific sport, you should follow a proper training plan. If you just want to "get strong" or "look big" then do whatever you want, since the specifics don't really matter.

>>69606555
Athletes (generous description) also need to factor in how much they can commit to training.
The long slow distance methods require a some significant time to work properly. If they have a max of 45 minutes a couple of times a week they might be better changing the balance of training to include some faster stuff (this is not uncommon with us masters athletes btw). I have tried several approaches over the years and was "fittest" on 70mpw with two longer slower runs and the rest recovery. I was quickest off 40ish mpw with a mix of paces, both 10k (31:3x) and h/m (69:3x) coming shortly after winters screwed by viruses and injuries (20,21 y/o). Then I couldn't up the time for training due to physical condition and studies.

>>69616746
Easy way round that (unless you live somewhere flat) is to run a hilly route once a week as a steady run. It will force you to run in different HR zones (unless you slow down) - not a bad thing, especially if you want to get involved in XC competitions, as it teaches you to deal with variable pace (racing).

Worrying about pace is pointless with XC (hilly or otherwise) as you might be on a mix of gravel, wooded path, dry or wet parkland, ploughed fields. Then there's an individual's capability over different surfaces...

Once I started paying more attention to heart rate and pace in my training I did notice my times start to drop. Most weeks I do 2 short (~5-6 mi.) easy runs, 1 long (10+ mi.) easy run, and 1 tempo run (varying distance).

My max. pace didn't necessarily increase but I was able to sustain it for longer and I could start to ramp up my pace near the end of a race sooner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69617711
Plantar problems suck. Can only really recommend:
- stretching carefully (grip heel one hand, pull toes back with the other)
- picking a towel up off floor gripping with toes
- carefully rolling hockey ball (or similar) on sole while applying pressure (don't overdo)
- run on grass
- change shoes
- don't lace shoe too tightly (stops foot flexing properly).

That last one has caused me all sorts of odd problems. Weight loss is a good thing too.

I first noticed some discomfort where my achilles meets my heel while doing weighted calf raises at full calf extension. Only on the left ankle. I stopped doing calf raises for a couple week because of that.
Kept running, but eventually started to feel soreness in the same spot after my runs. Stopped running for a week.
Then I had a work week that involved a lot of jumping off of ledges and ladders. Woke up one morning with tons of swelling and pain the same spot. It's painful to dorsiflex my foot when there is weight on it.
Bursitis? Tendonitis? Tips for prevention?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69619364
Most likely achilles tendonitis, pretty common when increasing mileage as a beginner. I had issues with it too, my only real advice is to rest it, make sure you're not trying to do too much, make sure your sleep and nutrition is on point, and maybe try taping it with kinesiology tape (it's not a solution but it did help speed up recovery for me a bit by letting me go for easy walks/jogs). https://youtu.be/T5NUbNkB_oA

>>69625951

Not only is the gram per pound of body weight rule a meme, it's based off of estimation of lean mass, not total body weight. And even then, you probably don't need that much. You probably only NEED .7-.8g / lb of LBM. And even then, that's only when you are trying to maximize gains to grow muscle. If you get around half a gram per pound of LBM you will definitely still see gains, it will only be suboptimal to a very small degree. Most of the protein digested is used as energy. The body only uses a very small amount for MPS.

Protein is the biggest meme in lifting culture. Almost everybody gets enough.. Remember: you're a regular unenhanced dyel just looking to get in shape, you do not need 200 grams of amino acids per day. The intensity, volume, and quality of your training is so much more important than getting in extra protein.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69626108
>So how do I eat at a calorie deficit and make sure I'm burning fat instead of muscle?

You keep lifting weights, and keep the deficit low. Those are by far the two most important things bare none. If you cut too fast, and are doing 1000+ kcal deficits daily, you're going to lose some muscle inevitably. If you don't keep training the muscle, you will lose it too obviously.

Now perhaps if you are actually protein deficient (<50g / day) it will cause accelerated loss of muscle during cut. But you would have to literally try to get this low. Even refined carbs like bread and rice have decent amounts of protein, vegetables have protein. As long as you eat regular food: meat, dairy, veges, etc. you'll be fine.

As long as you take your cut slow, continue to train hard, you'll look good at the end of your cut.

>Is an online calculator the only way to know my actual basal metabolic rate? Then using a smart watch to see how many extra calories I burn during my workout?
Yeah the calculators will give you an estimate. The only way you can really tell what works is experimenting. You use the estimates of both caloric intake and outtake and monitor the progress over time. If you aren't losing weight as projected after several weeks, your TDEE is probably lower than you think, if you are losing weight quickly, it's higher than you estimated. adjust as needed at that point.
>I think my gym offers a paid metabolic test, is it bullshit?
Unnecessary
>What's the ideal daily deficit amount to maximize fat loss during a cut?
Eating nothing. You probably meant to say: maximize muscle loss. Probably around a 300-500 calorie deficit would limit muscle loss.

Fruits contain compounds that help you digest the sugar (its meant to rot on the ground after all) and it's mixed forms of sugar as well instead of it just being straight up sucrose or something. The fiber also helps regulate blood sugar when eating the fruit on top of those compounds. I remember reading a study where they gave test subjects black currant juice and compared it against sugar water. The people drinking the juice had better hormonal responses to the juice than the sugar water even without the fiber there to further offset how much sugar is in it. When I've seen studies testing fruit against other carb and sugar sources it almost always wins. Our evolutionary history started humans as frugivores (fruit reliant herbivores) and we didn't stop eating them throughout that history. If there's any source of sugar and carbs that's good for you it's fruit

Video and especially "livestreaming" are inherently worse media for information transmission, definitely for self improvement content. There's nothing a video can say that a book or article can't say more concisely and to the point, while having all the advantages of a piece of text, like skipping around and prioritizing as an audience member. The only reason people prefer video is because it adds an "entertainment" factor, meaning channels who talk about this are entertainment first, advice second. They are influencers, adding useless fluff to the information conveyed, rehashing old concepts for watchtime, building parasocial trust and then monetizing this wasted time with sponsors.
A self help video inherently wastes your time compared to alternatives and rarely does the medium have advantages for those types of content. Even when it does, in sum it's a net negative.
It might be different for fitness channels, because they can convey form etc. better, but I guess that rarely is better in video form than it can be done in photos in a book. Still, at least there's some argument that video might be good for that topic.

Shadow boxing alone? Not really. I mean it’s ok, but it’s not all that great. You’re much, much better off using a heavy bag for cardio. It’s my go-to for cardio for a few reasons. The biggest is because when I hit legs, they’re basically useless afterward, so any cardio involving my legs is seriously lacking on those days. And it shows; I can never keep my heart rate where I want it when I’m doing a dedicated leg day. But on any upper body day I can still work in a heavy bag routine.

It’s also a lot less mundane than jogging or using a machine. I mean you can just phone it in and go through the motions, but you can also really concentrate on form and speed.

Another alternative to shadow boxing is using a slip line. It’s much more involved than just throwing punches. And again, there’s more to concentrate on.

I don’t. I used to only do all my cheat exercises with dumbbells and it wasn’t fixing my problem. The reason I chose machines was because I could guarantee myself that each side was doing the exact same range of motion and lifting the same weight. I made sure to go to failure that way the smaller side was putting in the same amount of work. And it eventually began to even out. I’d recommend a curl machine but those usually have only one weight that both arms share in lifting. If you can find one that has a separate weight for each side I think that could help you.

>>69624804
>>69624865


>What are good sources to buy from?
Private sources, trust nothing on discord or anywhere that has a publicly accessible website. (I'm looking at you eroids)
>What stack would you recommend?
Best first cycle is always just test. 500-600mg/week. Avoid everything else until you have a baseline on this.
>What routine should I use to optimize my
Creeping death 2, modified Jeff Nippard PPL.
I personally do bro split+PPL seven days lifting.
Monday through Friday bro split quick intense 30 minute isolations
Fri Legs
Sat Push
Sunday Pull


Before you hop on cycle find a good forum to join, like an old school 2006 forum full of old heads and smart guys. That's the only way you'll learn.

Have AI and all of your pct ancillaries on hand before you ever start any compound. Aromasin will not crash your e2 and arimidex is very harsh although much cheaper can easily crash your e2.
Crashed e2 is the worst feeling in the world.
Have ralox on hand for gyno just in case.

Buy 2-3 years worth at a time.
Use Bitcoin nothing else.


You have a decent foundation but steroids will not make up for lack of diet and training or lack of knowledge and discipline.
When you come off cycle you will lose a ton of weight.
Say you gain 30 lbs in 16 weeks on 500mg test, that'll turn into 10 lbs of muscle, 20 lbs water and glycogen.

Get bloodwork done before during and after to learn your body. Don't take an AI before getting your bloodwork done.

I can go on and on and on.

>>69624804
I have been on for years now. Some advice:
They don't do what you want unless you work hard in the gym and have your diet down. Have seen plenty of fat weak idiots run a cycle to try to magically fix their shit without success. You will be able to increase volume and intensity quicker than usual so this should be your aim (without snapping your shit).
Low doses get results. High doses get more results and side effects. If you just wanna be sexy (rather than huge/strong) then halving most internet quoted doses is sensible. Similarly, there's little benefit to using orals or exotic compounds unless it's e.g. contest prep.
Never trust UGLs. You will be likely forced to deal with them but they always have the potential and clear incentives to fuck you.

Natural hypertrophy Baki weight training novice program https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dfnn-YdXerg
Day 1:
Squats (3 sets, 4 to 8 reps) + Band shrugs AMRAP
Romanian deadlifts (4 sets, 8 to 12 reps) + Pull-ups AMRAP
Skullcrushers (4 sets, 8 to 12 reps) + Band Curls (4 sets, AMRAP)
Push ups + Leg raises + Neck curls / extensions + Band Calf raises AMRAP (∞ sets)

Day 2:
Bench (3 sets, 6 to 10 reps) + Band shrugs (horizontal torso) AMRAP
OHP (4 sets, 6 to 10 reps) + Chin-ups AMRAP
Back hyperextensions (4 sets, 8 to 12 reps) + Ring rows AMRAP
Diamond push ups + Crunches + Neck side raises + Band Calf raises AMRAP (∞ sets)

Day 3:
Deadlifts (1 to 3 heavy sets, 2 to 5 reps)
Pause squats (4 sets, 6 to 10 reps) + Pull-ups AMRAP
Shrugs (4 sets, 10 to 15 reps) + Facepulls AMRAP
Push ups + Leg raises + Neck curls / extensions + Band Calf raises AMRAP (∞ sets)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Professional mattress tester here (I work in the R&D department of a mattress company you've heard of).
There's no one-size-fits-all for mattress type, nor for sleeping position.
Generally, if you're heavier you should probably sleep on your side, but whatever posiion you naturally find yourself sleeping in is your best bet.
Go to a bunch of mattress stores and try as many mattresses as you can, this'll help you work out what sort of plushness is right for you.
Once you work out what feel is good, try to spend a good 15 minutes lying on each mattress to identify which one is the most comfortably.
Once you've worked out what feel you want in store. you can take advantage the fact that most online 'bed in a box' mattress sellers offer a 100 day no questions asked return policy (though be aware you're going to need to spend at least a month sleeping on a new mattress to break it in and for your body to adapt).
A more expensive mattress from a reputable brand is more likely to be the right mattress for you, but everyone's body is different, so don't feel like you have to spend more if you're comfortable on a cheaper one.

>>69623003
Let me tell you what I've learned about bread so far.
From a weight loss perspective there's almost no fucking difference between them. Whole wheat flour is almost the same calories per gram as high fructose corn syrup.
From a hunger satiety standpoint it's not the best or the worst. The more open the crumb the better it will work (because it's bigger with less calories.) A tortilla with fat in it will be less likely to sugar crash you than a whole wheat bread slice, I think the bread with fat in it is more satisfying, but fat will up the calorie content whereas sugar won't (by weight that is. If the sugar makes the bread heavier than it makes the calorie content go up to. It's all about density.)
>Wheat flour semite
It's not the wheat, it's one of two things. Either you're getting GMO wheat and it's doing to you what is designed to do to the bugs, or it's the additives. Bake your own bread and use only pure ingredients. Don't use bleached or fortified flour. Get your vitamins from food or pills if you must.
Most people simply avoid the stuff. There's nothing intrinsically wrong with bread, but it's high calorie content and the difficulty and expense of getting pure product make it more of a pain than it's worth. If you can't do it right and in moderation, avoid it.

>>69625750
You have to straight arm raise the bar from the ground. Most people can't lift that weight using only their shoulder.

This is significantly tougher compared to doing it normally - when you perform a front raise normally, the starting position has your arm nearly straight down. From that position, it takes significantly less energy and leverage to get the weight moving. By the time your arm is straight out, you've built a bit of momentum to keep the weight moving. Because this challenge has you starting the motion with your arm straight out, you need way more energy to get the weight moving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69626922
You seem very young. This board will make you miserable and you should leave before it gives you body dysmorphia. Before you go though, I’ll try to help.
Your right arm is easier to flex and stronger because it is your dominant arm, obviously. You have a stronger neuromuscular connection with it, so you can activate it better, and it feels like you are working it. You are not using your forearm to curl with your left arm, your left forearm is just weaker, so it gets noticeably sore when your right doesn’t.
You should do bicep curls in a controlled way if you are worried about imbalances. Putting your back against a wall and curling with a barbell, sitting on a slightly declined bench, and the preacher curl are all good ways to do so. Don’t worry too much about fill it though, you will gain a better feeling of control over your left arm as you continue to lift.

posts.com:
>>69626922
>Beginner here, when i do dumbbell curls i dont feel activation or pump on my left bicep, but i do on my right. On my left it feels like my forearm works more than the bicep.
Seems like you have a imbalance where one forearm/arm is weaker then the other. This will fix it self really quick if you just keep training.

>My biggest concern is that my forearm will just get stronger instead of my bicep and my bicep will stay not defined
What is happening is that your forearm is a lot weaker due to being untrained and maybe underused in real life. These sort of things are normal and will fix them self and even out.

>What i try to do with the 8kg dumbbells is the same amount of reps on my right arm as my left arm because i dont want my right bicep getting bigger while my left arm doesnt.
This is normal and people will always be a little stronger on side of their body. The difference tend to be 1-2 reps strength difference. Again as you train imbalances will sort them self out and you don't have to worry about it, but some imbalances are normal and you will never ever fix them and that is how it also is with professional lifters and athletes.

>Also i feel like i cant flex my left bicep as well as my right one.
Again, this is normal, people are uneven like this and will be like that for ever. The world hardest punchers will always punch harder with one arm, the worlds best throwers will always throw better with one arm. The worlds biggest bodybuilders will always have asymmetry in their muscles that they cannot fix where one is bigger then the other. The worlds best arm wrestlers always use one arm for a reason.. Its stronger.

>Do i keep trying to progress with that weight even tho i feel like my left bicep isnt working at all?
Yes. What you can do since you are new is to do one arm at the time and do your weakest first, then repeat with the strong arm what you did with the weakest. your imbalance will fix it self quickly, its there because you are untrained

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69624728
>>thoracic erectors are highly underrated; you can train them by rounding and extending your thoracic spine on chest supported rows
>What about jefferson curls?
Good but you're going to be limited by your lumbar erectors, while on chest supported rows you can work the thoracic erectors without involving the lumbar ones. Still a great exercise for lower back bulletproofing.
>>the rectus femoris does not get adequatly stimulated by squatting, you need to isolate it
>Why and how?
The rectus femoris crosses the hip joint, and it both extends the knee and flexes the hip. During a squat, you undergo simultaneous hip and knee flexion and extension, meaning that the rectus femoris lengthens at one end while shortening at the other on both the negative and the positive on the squat, meaning it never really lengthens or contracts much during the lift. You need to do a movement that isolates knee extension. Sissy squats and reverse nordics are probably the best option because they hit the rectus femoris in the lengthened position, but both of them are very hard on your knees (I'd favor the sissy squat as the reverse nordic seems to be even harder on the knees) so you shouldn't use that much volume (which is fine anyway because 3 sets is more than enough to fuck up your rec fem). Other than that leg extensions work too, but you'll need to do a lot more volume as they're the most challenging in the shortened position which is generally less stimulative (Use intensity techniques like partials, drop sets, myo reps etc on these so you don't have to do as many).

>>forearm training is very important for aesthetics, large upper arm but small lower arm looks very unaesthetic
>Reverse curls?
Reverse curls are money, they're the most bang for your buck forearm exercise. Do em with an ez bar, no cheating using hips/back/shoulders, slow eccentric, wrist wraps, and don't use a thumbless grip. Though I still recommend doing flexion/extension movements for full development.
Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69624728
>>69624801
>>powell raises are amazing for rear delts
>I tried this a few times and it felt awkward as fuck. Are there any helpful cues?
Use a slow eccentric, make sure your upper arm is going across your upper pec at the bottom of the movement, try to make sure your body stays stable during the movement. I do agree that it is a little awkward however it is MUCH more stimulative than most other rear delt exercises because it challenges the rear delts in the stretched position, so you don't have to do like 7 sets of rear delts with rest pause, drop sets, partials etc to get enough stimulus.
>>on exercises where adding reps is extremely hard but adding small amounts of weight is easy, static rep pyramids are also better than static rep ranges. instead of 3x8 for example, you would do 9/8/7 reps
>Example?
3 count pause bulgarian split squats. That's actually what made me come up with this, because I fucking hated trying to do more reps, but adding 1kg felt hardly any different. Front squats apply here to an extent as well.
>>training the tibialis anterior and the soleus can help fix knee/shin pain from high impact activities, soleus is also important for achilles tendon health
>Even rooners?
Especially rooners actually, because the tibialis anterior absorbs forces that would otherwise go into the knee. Both of them together can help stop shin splints as well iirc.
>>pecmaxxers should train their pec minor for even more growth, most people entirely overlook this muscle
>Deep stretch with ring movements?
That's good for pecs in general, but I would say that your best bet for specifically targeting the pec minor is pec minor dips. https://youtu.be/4HnIGSTOwnE Do them frequently as your pec minor recovers fast, make sure to add weight. If you feel like your chest is being pushed out after doing a set of these, you're doing it right as that's the pec minor pump pushing out the pec major.

>>69625095
>cookie cutter programs written by people who don't know anything about your individual differences and preferences
Any program written by yourself outside of the novice stage (since novices have no idea what the fuck they are doing) will be infinitely better since you can actually customize everything according to what your goals are, your individual differences and preferences, etc. If you train for hypertrophy, you're going to have an ideal you're striving towards, and this will not be the same from person to person as people will have different preferences in terms of how big or small they want certain muscles to be. Some people want big legs, others want slimmer ones, some people want a huge gorilla chest, others want the plate-chest look, some people want death star delts, others just want proportional delts, etc. The vast majority of cookie cutter programs do not account for any of this, let alone the fact that most people will need different amounts of volume for each muscle group (I do 22 sets of horizontal pressing a week at 0-2 RIR (yes my shoulders are fine), SS has only 9 sets every 2 weeks. My chest would get nowhere near enough stimulus if I were to run SS. Upper back would be even worse as there is no rowing at all in the program).

Point is, make your own program and follow your own path instead of someone else's.

>interdasting...
>I know you have to work up to being able to do a full one with your back completely on the floor at the bottom. Is it safe to load once you can comfortably do a set? Sissy squats look gay as fuck and I refuse to do them.
If you don't get any pain it's probably fine, but even when I used band assistance it still fucked with my knees. Sissy squats, though they are still hard on the knees, are much easier on them than reverse nordics so I do them instead. Also do these with a slow eccentric and pause, it helps quite a lot. I don't see how sissy squats are faggy aside from the name (should be manly squats ngl they're hard as hell), they're just a squat where you keep your hips locked and go onto your toes so that you can reach maximal knee flexion.
>I guess I don't understand what differentiates this with a bent over rear delt fly. Would a reverse pec deck be just as stimulative?
It's different because in a bent over rear delt fly / reverse pec deck you do not get a full stretch of the rear delt, while you do on a powell raise. Plus especially on bent over flyes the hardest position is the contracted position, there is very little tension in the bottom position. On powell raises there is no tension in the contracted position, but there is tension in the stretched position. Anyway, you would need to do a lot more of reverse pec deck to get the same stimulus as powell raises, but if you prefer it then by all means do it, just know that you will have to accrue a lot more volume to get the same effect. Again, for those movements use partials, drop sets, myoreps, etc to accumulate volume more quickly so you waste less time.

>>69625354
Accessory lifts are a strength-training concept; nothing is an accessory lift in hypertrophy training because EVERYTHING is necessary. And besides this most "accessory" lifts tend to be 1 exercise for each major muscle group involved in a compound lift (as an example for bench, pec flies for chest, front raises for front delts, pushdowns for triceps), typically done something along the lines of 5x10 or 3x12 (big sandbagging due to static rep ranges, and because they're "accessories" people don't push them hard anyway, and they wonder why their arms are shit 4 years later). This also means that many small muscles that are both vitally important for injury prevention and aesthetics get entirely neglected (The most forearm work you'll find in a strength program is some grip work, which is mediocore for forearms at best due to its isometric nature and the fact that it only targets 1 part of the forearm. You're lucky to find rear delt work at all, and external rotator work is much much rarer still. Nothing for the lower traps, or thoracic erectors, both very important for a thick back. Upper traps is more common but still not that common. Adductor work is rare but becoming less rare as people realize how important adductor work is for preventing tweaks when squatting. Calf work is almost never present either but if it is there isn't much volume and it's half-assed. Abs are either skipped entirely or are trained very lazily because muh squatz and deadz are enough right guys?? Upper chest is there sometimes but not all the time, and biceps tend to be an afterthought since they don't contribute at all to the big 3. I have never ever seen neck training in any of these programs either, of course it does not contribute at all to the big 3 either so it makes sense.)

I've been lifting and studying fitness for nearly 15 years now and this thread is gold. Except for one point made

Both are equally important. Doing all squeeze with heavy loads vs all stretch with heavy loads will yield the same results. Working both ends of the strength curve gives you maximum hypertrophy. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69625621
Probably should have elaborated a bit more then, I don't mean that the squeeze should be entirely avoided, more that the stretch is generally more important as it tends to produce greater stimulus on a set per set basis, so I think it should be prioritized, eg sissy squats vs leg extensions, for example, you'll generally need more sets of leg extensions to get the same volume as fewer sets of sissy squats. If you can get both in the same movement you have an absolute gem (ring pushups are the best example of this IMO). Another benefit of movements that are the most difficult in the contracted position is that they tend to be very easy on the tendons and are good for getting lots of bloodflow, which can help fix tendon/joint pain.

I'll add these points to that section for the next time I post this thread, thanks bro.

Sandbagging is when you intentionally hold back from using all your effort. If it is intentional it's fine, but in the case of static rep ranges it is unintentional. The problem lies in the fact that the earlier sets in a static rep range are much easier, while the ones later are much harder. Rep ranges are better because you can use consistent effort, for example if you're doing a 5x5 on squats your first set could be 4 reps from failure, second 3 reps, third 2 reps, fourth 1, fifth 0.5 (could do same reps with a little more weight). Numbers are just an example but you get the point. Meanwhile on a 4x8-12, you might get 11, 10, 9, 9 but every set could be roughly 1 rep from failure give or take a little for example. If you tried to go to failure on your first set on a 5x5, you wouldn't be able to get 5 reps on the next set, so you will always be quite a few reps from failure on that first set. While on a rep range, you can go to failure just fine since on your next set you'll just get fewer reps, but as long as it still falls within the rep range that's fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69626123
>Ask what type of movements you want specifically
What are some obscure alternatives for quad and hamstring/posterior chain work for someone with a homegym with only dumbbells, backpack, various bands etc?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69626196
>quads
Sissy squats, but be very careful with these as you can give yourself patellar tendonitis quite easily if you aren't prepared for it. Maybe stay away from it until you're sure your knees are bulletproof enough.
ATG split squats, these are very difficult so dumbbells and/or backpack will suffice for quite a while. If you don't have the mobility or you get knee pain, elevate your front foot to the point where this goes away, and over time you will be able to progress to flat ground.
3 count pause bulgarian split squats, these are hard as fuck. They do use quite a lot of glutes and adductors but I suppose that's fine. Stick with slightly lower reps due to the pause duration.
If you can elevate your heels you can also do goblet squats for high reps, this would be good at the end of a leg session.
>hamstrings
Nordic curls if you can set them up, band assisted is ideal until you can do full reps. Negatives are fine too though
DB RDLs, go as deep as possible every rep, keep your knees back, make sure your back is neutral or arched. Maybe try single leg too as you won't need as much weight, but you do need a hand free to stabilize if you want to use it for hypertrophy.
You could also do leg curls with the bands but it isn't a particularly good exercise desu
>adductors
Weighted tailor's pose for reps and db seated good mornings. These on top of everything else should be enough. If you want more, maybe try training for the middle splits as that would provide more stimulus for the adductors
>erectors
Jefferson curls + aforementioned seated good mornings, that's about it. Progress very slowly and carefully on the jefferson curls though.
>hip flexors
L-sit

>dropsets
Unnecessary as a noob but if you like them it won't hurt to keep them in
>the arm program
What you've written is good if you're easily bored, but I'd recommend getting it down to fewer and fewer exercises until you have 1 long head focused tricep lift, 1 heavy tricep lift, and 2 curls you can do twice per week
>SS
>need mass
You're wasting your time sticking with that then. Known noob trap. Alter it to change the reps on everything but the deadlifts to 8-12. Double the amount of upper body compounds for everything but OHP, which you should include a lateral raise and a rear delt raise superset to get a balanced shoulder. Also add some calf raises. A bodybuilding program has a lower body list that can fit on a stickynote but an upper body list that would need a legal pad. For the chest in particular make that second compound an incline press. You'll get stronger over time regardless of your rep range unless you're trying to hit heavy singles, doubles, and triples. That's partially a specialized skill. Size requires more volume than strength does
